rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 17   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 15   Value: 9
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 23   Value: 12
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 10   Value: 21
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 8    Value: 40
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
I currently have:  
Wheat 17 (5) | Wood 15 (9) | Sheep 23 (12) | Brick 10 (21) | Ore 8 (40)

Immediate calculation of the present value:  
17·5 + 15·9 + 23·12 + 10·21 + 8·40 = 85 + 135 + 276 + 210 + 320 = 1 026 points.

I notice Ore is by far the highest-point resource (40 points each), I only have 8 of them, and the 17 Wheat and 15 Wood are my lowest-value holdings. Using one Ore in a trade is expensive (costing 40 points), so I want to swap my weaker resources for even just a small additional quantity of Ore or Brick (21 points), while offering only what costs me the least.

Turn 1  
Small initial proposal to see how the other player reacts.

[Offer: 5 Wheat, 2 Wood → 1 Ore]

17 ⋅ 5  = 85  
15 ⋅ 9  = 135  
23 ⋅ 12 = 276  
10 ⋅ 21 = 210

TOTAL = 1 026 VP

My cheapest resources are Wheat (5 VP) and Wood (9 VP); my most expensive are Ore (40 VP) and Brick (21 VP).  
I begin with 10 Brick but 40 VP each, so even small gains there can matter.

Turn 1 – Initial offer  
I want to move low-value Wheat/Wood into high-value Brick/Sheep without over-paying.  
I will risk only two Wheat (total value = 10 VP) and offer them for a single Brick (21 VP), giving me a +11 VP swing.

[Offer: 2 Wheat -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
It's turn 2 out of 10.  
Last turn my 2-for-1 Wheat-for-Brick proposal was rejected, so I need to sweeten the pot.  

I want more Brick because its marginal value to me (21) is much higher than Wheat’s (5), yet 2 Wheat is only worth 10 total. Offering 3 Wheat brings the value offered to 15, which is still below Brick’s value but is closer, and adding 1 Brick on my side should now look attractive to Player 1 while still making me a tidy profit.

[Offer: 3 Wheat, 1 Brick -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
I see the history:

- Turn 1 I offered “2 Wheat → 1 Brick”; Player-1 denied.  
- Turn 2 Player-1 made no new offer; everything else is “denied.”  
- Turn 3 I offered “3 Wheat, 1 Brick → 2 Brick”; Player-1 denied.  
- Turn 4 Player-1 still has made no new offer, so nothing for me to accept or deny.

To keep the initiative I will try again, making the offer slightly richer so it is more attractive to Player-1 while still improving my total value.

Current situation for me:

- Brick (value 21) is my scarcest resource but also the one I want to accumulate—every extra brick gains me 21 points.  
- Wheat (value 5) is my lowest-value surplus (17 on hand).

Reasonable small trade that still gains me value: offer one ore (value 40) and ask for two brick (value 42). The net value I gain is +2, low risk, and Player-1 might find two brick for one ore attractive if they lack ore.

[Offer: 1 Ore -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let me reassess my current holdings and prioritise the next moves.  
Turn summary so far:

- T8: I sent 1 Ore and got back 2 Brick (net: lose 1 Ore worth 40, gain 1 Brick worth 21 ⇒ –19 value this turn).  
- With Ore dropping to 7, Ore is still my scarcest resource; Wheat, Wood & Sheep are still the ones I’m most willing to spare.

Current stock and unit values (turn end T8):
- Wheat 17×5 = 85  
- Wood 15×9 = 135  
- Sheep 23×12 = 276  
- Brick 9×21  = 189 (just gained 1)  
- Ore 7×40   = 280  
Total = 965

Next steps / turn rationale for T9:
1. Continue to dump Wheat / Sheep for Brick at least 2-for-1 to offset the Ore premium I just paid.  
2. Unlock the Brick → Ore “banking” route once Brick ≥3 excess (need 3 Brick:1 Ore).  
3. Only make single-sided offers; Player 1 so far never proposes anything.

I prepare one new offer:

[Offer: 3 Wheat -> 2 Brick]

Let me first tabulate what happened so far and what the new board looks like.

Starting inventory (after every accepted trade):

• 17 Wheat  (worth 5 each)  
• 15 Wood   (worth 9 each)  
• 23 Sheep  (worth 12 each)  
• 10 Brick  (worth 21 each)  
• 8 Ore     (worth 40 each)

Accepted trades so far:

1) Turn 4 → [Offer: 1 Ore → 2 Brick] (accepted)  
   - Ore dropped from 8 → 7  
   - Brick rose from 10 → 12  

Current inventory before next move:

• Wheat 17 (no change)  
• Wood  15  
• Sheep 23  
• Brick 12  
• Ore   7  

Incoming offer that is pending on me right now:

[Received]  Offer: 5 Wheat + 1 Brick → 1 Ore

Evaluation  
- Value I’d give away: 5·5 + 1·21 = 25 + 21 = 46  
- Value I’d receive: 1·40 = 40  

Net loss of 6 value → I reject.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
I'll evaluate my current position and make a strategic trade offer for Turn 7.

After reviewing the previous trades:
- I traded 1 Ore (value 40) for 2 Brick (value 42), which was a +2 value gain
- My current resources should be:
  - Wheat: 17 - (2+3+3) = 9
  - Wood: 15
  - Sheep: 23
  - Brick: 10 + 2 - 1 - 1 = 10
  - Ore: 8 - 1 = 7

My assets currently have a total value of:
(9×5) + (15×9) + (23×12) + (10×21) + (7×40) = 45 + 135 + 276 + 210 + 280 = 946

Looking at the values:
- I have excess Sheep (23 units at 12 each)
- Brick at 21 value seems good, and Ore at 40 is excellent
- I should acquire more Ore and maintain Brick levels

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 1 Wheat -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
My current holdings (and value changes after last trade ― I gave away 1 Ore for 2 Brick):

• Wheat 17 (-1 net via rejected deals, so still ~17) : 5  → 85 value  
• Wood 15 : 9  → 135 value  
• Sheep 23 : 12 → 276 value  
• Brick 10 + 2 gained = 12 : 21 → 252 value  
• Ore 8 – 1 = 7         : 40 → 280 value  

Total value ≈ 1 028 points.

Ore is by far the scarcest & most valuable per-unit brick, and Brick is a nice mid-tier good I now have twelve of.  Since Player 1 keeps bidding for Ore (they tried to give me 5 Wheat + 1 Brick for 1 Ore in the last turn), they’re clearly Ore-thirsty.  Sheep are cheap to me (12 pts each) and I have 23 of them.  I’m willing to part with some Sheep if I can get back Ore, but at a steeper ratio than they just proposed.

I’ll now make a counter offer that still looks tempting for them—4 Sheep for 1 Ore—which is more Sheep per Ore than the market ratios I’ve previously proposed, but still below their own bid yardstick.

[Offer: 4 Sheep -> 1 Ore]

0.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.

1.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.
